title: PTD Today — Media
disclaimer: Informational only — AI-generated summaries; may contain errors. Verify with the original video.

items.title: How AI Empowers Artists. Watch the full episode on our channel now.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this short film accompanies Season 5 of the Webby Award–winning podcast Where the Internet Lives and explores the intersection of AI, data and creativity—specifically how AI empowers artists. It frames those creative uses against the unseen infrastructure of data centers that make AI and online creative tools possible.
bullets: Companion film to Season 5 of Where the Internet Lives (Webby Award–winning podcast).
Focuses on AI’s role in empowering artists and creative workflows.
Situates creative AI within the ‘unseen world’ of data centers and infrastructure.
Highlights themes: AI, data, creativity and the infrastructure that supports them.
Full episode is available on the channel (Google).
takeaways: Creative AI use cases can drive increased compute demand—plan for scalable power and cooling capacity to support model training and inference workloads.
Data centers enabling creative AI may benefit from integrated renewables and storage to handle variable, high-power loads while managing operating costs and emissions.
Procurement and capacity planning should account for GPU-heavy hardware and the critical minerals supply chain that underpins AI acceleration.
Engage creative-sector customers early to size capacity, service-level expectations, and latency/collocation needs tied to artistic workflows.
Visibility into how creative applications consume compute can inform demand-response, load-shaping and contractual arrangements with grid operators.

items.title: Boosting AI Performance: Networking for AI Inference

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Victor Moreno outlines how Google Cloud is making networking "AI-aware" to improve inference performance by using the GKE Inference Gateway, AI-aware load balancing, and service extensions. These techniques (inference-specific metrics, prefix caching, body-based routing and in‑network guardrails) aim to raise GPU utilization, cut latency and lower total cost of ownership while streamlining developer workflows.
bullets: Uses inference-specific metrics (e.g., KV cache utilization, queue depth) to identify least-loaded replicas rather than relying on CPU metrics.
Prefix caching and shadow cache copies let the gateway reuse prefill computations to reduce GPU work and cold starts.
Body-based routing and LoRA adapter awareness enable model identification and smarter request steering.
Service Extensions allow inserting API management and AI guardrails at the network layer to sanitize prompts/responses before they hit GPUs.
Result: improved GPU saturation, reduced latency and cost, and centralized security/governance at the edge.
takeaways: Higher GPU utilization from AI-aware networking can lower per-inference energy use and reduce peak power demands in data centers.
Reducing cold starts and wasted GPU cycles can smooth power draw, aiding substation/load planning and UPS/cooling capacity sizing.
Edge guardrails that block invalid requests before model execution save compute (and associated energy) and reduce unnecessary hardware wear.
More efficient use of GPUs can reduce the number of required accelerators, influencing procurement needs tied to critical minerals and hardware lifecycle.
Unified routing and service extension patterns simplify operations, which can lower rack density and cooling design pressure over time.

items.title: Where Winds Meet is #RTXOn with DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the video showcases the open-world martial arts RPG Where Winds Meet running with NVIDIA features: DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation and #RTXOn. Footage is credited to DigitalDreamsyt and no transcript was provided.
bullets: Open-world martial arts RPG: Where Winds Meet
Features DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation
Uses RTX on (real-time ray tracing) as indicated by #RTXOn
Visual footage credited to DigitalDreamsyt
No transcript available in the provided content
takeaways: Use of DLSS 4, Multi Frame Generation and RTX implies reliance on high-performance GPUs—plan for higher power and cooling needs in edge and data-center render nodes.
Advances in frame-generation and upscaling may increase effective throughput per GPU, affecting capacity planning for cloud gaming and rendering services.
Trailers and streaming of graphically intensive titles can create short-term spikes in power demand—consider demand-response, battery/UPS provisioning, and thermal headroom.
Broader adoption of advanced GPUs sustains long-term demand for GPUs and related supply-chain materials, which has implications for critical-minerals procurement and lifecycle planning.

items.title: The backbone of your steam plant’s reliability | GE Vernova

ai.summary: Based on the available description, GE Vernova highlights the importance of anticipating the remaining life of aging steam turbine rotors and deciding appropriate next steps to preserve steam plant reliability. The video points viewers to GE Vernova’s rotor end-of-life resource and frames this work within the company’s broader mission to electrify and decarbonize energy.
bullets: Focus: anticipate an aging steam turbine rotor’s remaining life to sustain plant reliability.
Action-oriented: guidance on what to do next for rotor end-of-life (EOL) planning.
Resource: link provided to GE Vernova’s rotor EOL information.
Channel: GE Vernova promotes subscribing and connecting via its web and social channels.
Context: positioned within GE Vernova’s electrification and decarbonization efforts.
takeaways: Prioritize rotor EOL assessment in asset-management plans to reduce unplanned outages and preserve supply to grids and critical loads like data centers.
Include OEM resources (e.g., GE Vernova rotor EOL guidance) when planning replacements, life extensions, or refurbishments.
Treat rotor life planning as part of broader reliability and decarbonization strategies for thermal assets alongside renewables and storage integration.

items.title: Rynek dóbr luksusowych w obliczu transformacji | Andrzej Marczak, Tomasz Wiśniewski

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this KPMG ON AIR episode reviews trends reshaping the luxury goods market—shift to experience-first consumption, growth of "affordable luxury", rising ESG expectations, and personalization—while noting Poland's market growth despite global declines. Speakers also discuss luxury hospitality, the art market, aspirational consumers, and future drivers such as AI, craftsmanship and the human dimension.
bullets: Experience over ownership: Gen Z and many buyers prefer experiences; luxury fatigue is emerging.
Top-tier concentration: the wealthiest ~2% account for ~40% of the market.
ESG and responsible luxury are rising priorities (e.g., eco-leathers, certifications).
Poland: growing but fragmented luxury market with expanding aspirational segments and new product categories.
Luxury tourism, hotels, spas and the art market are notable growth areas; future themes include AI and bespoke craftsmanship.
takeaways: Rising luxury tourism and premium hospitality activity implies localized, high-quality power needs—plan for resilience (backup generation, storage, microgrids) and strict environmental controls.
Stronger ESG/ certification demand favors on-site renewables procurement and verified green power solutions for premium venues and brands.

Greater personalization and AI-driven services suggest higher data-processing needs—anticipate capacity growth and prioritize energy-efficient data-center deployments or edge/colocation close to luxury hubs.
Fragmented, local luxury growth and event-driven peaks argue for flexible demand management and distributed energy resources to mitigate grid stress.
ESG and technology shifts may affect supply chains (including materials/tech used in luxury goods); monitor critical-minerals exposure and recycling/ circularity options for risk mitigation.

items.title: PJM: Reliable Electricity is Our Priority

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the video emphasizes PJM Interconnection's long-standing focus on reliability since 1927 and explains how the organization works to make sure electricity is available when you need it. It presents an informational overview of PJM's role in ensuring dependable power delivery.
bullets: PJM has prioritized reliability since its founding in 1927.
The video highlights reliability as PJM’s top objective.
It explains how PJM works to ensure electricity is available when needed.
Content is presented as an informational overview of PJM’s role.
Aimed at explaining PJM’s responsibilities in keeping the lights on.
takeaways: Treat PJM as a primary regional partner when planning for grid reliability and outage coordination.
Incorporate PJM reliability considerations into data center site selection, redundancy, and backup-power strategies.
Monitor PJM communications and planning updates to align operational and resiliency plans with regional conditions.
Use PJM’s reliability focus as a rationale to prioritize investments in resilient infrastructure and contingency resources.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the video frames grid modernization as a need to balance reliability, flexibility, and efficiency while expanding capacity to support the energy transition. It highlights Hitachi Energy’s digital‑centered power grid technologies aimed at improving stability, reducing downtime, and optimizing performance across the system.
bullets: Power systems must balance reliability, flexibility and efficiency while scaling capacity for the energy transition.
Hitachi Energy positions digital technologies as central to grid modernization.
Digital solutions are presented as means to improve stability and reduce downtime.
Optimization of performance is emphasized across all system levels.
takeaways: Prioritize digital‑first grid solutions that target stability and downtime reduction when planning upgrades.
Plan capacity expansions with an emphasis on flexibility and efficiency to accommodate more renewables and storage.
Assess vendors on their ability to deliver system‑wide performance optimization through digital tools.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the video frames industrial resilience around energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration. Hitachi Energy positions itself as a partner to help customers and partners build smarter systems that boost productivity, reliability, and sustainability across operations.
bullets: Focus on energy efficiency as a foundation for resilient industries
Process optimization to improve operational productivity
Digital integration to enhance reliability and decision-making
Partnerships with customers and partners to deploy smarter systems
Outcome emphasis: improved productivity, reliability, and sustainability
takeaways: Prioritize energy-efficiency upgrades to reduce risk and operating cost across grids and data centers
Invest in digital tools that enable process optimization and real‑time reliability monitoring
Seek technology partners (e.g., Hitachi Energy) for integrated solutions tying renewables, storage, and legacy infrastructure
Design projects to balance productivity gains with sustainability targets to future-proof operations
